The economy was overwhelmingly the major issue here in Michigan, more obviously than in Iowa or New Hampshire.

He had piled up a list of endorsements, drawing on his father's years as governor back in the '60s.
He raised far more money, spent way more money than any other candidate in Michigan.

Romney turned that to his benefit.

Romney went around saying, look, Michigan is in my DNA.
The automobile industry is in my bloodstream.

I'm going to bring Michigan back.

I'm on your side.
I'm going to turn things around for you.

The real question is, is it going to be effective if he uses that theme in other states - whatever state he goes to and competes hard in.

He made it sound almost - if you listen to the falling stock prices on Wall Street and the potentially looming recession, as though - and he used this metaphor, Michigan is the canary in the mineshaft, and that things are bad in Michigan.

The fact of the matter is that really isn't what's happened here in Michigan.

I think he's gotten that out of the way and I think he'll try to continue on the theme of the economy if he can do it.
